:"SOCl2" redirects here.

'Thionyl chloride' is an inorganic compound with the formula SOCl 2.
It is a reactive chemical used as a reagent in chlorination reactions. It is a
colorless, distillable liquid at room temperature and pressure that decomposes
above 140 Â°C. Thionyl chloride is sometimes confused with sulfuryl
chloride, SO 2Cl 2, but the properties of these compounds
differ significantly. Approximately 45,000 tons per year of
SOCl 2 were produced in the early 1990s. Hans-Dietrich Lauss,
Wilfried Steffens âSulfur Halidesâ in Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial
Chemistry Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2005.
